title: AMP planners to sue by Christmas
text:
AMP planners are angry with the firm after it reneged on a promise to buy back financial advice firms from aligned advisers at a longstanding multiple of four times recurring revenue and slashed the price to 2.5 times.

Some advisers have bought practices from other members of AMP’s planner network at the multiple of four times using money borrowed from AMP, only to find themselves underwater on the investment and being told the company no longer wished to be associated with them.

News of the Christmas target date has arrived on the back of AMP’s decision to extend the Halloween deadline for advisers the company is looking to shed.

As part of the process advisers unwanted by AMP have been told to accept a generous “one-off offer” or subject themselves to the more vigorous audit process.

Under the terms of the deal, advice practices targeted by AMP have been promised a once-over-lightly audit and planners would be given an accelerated exit from AMP. They could also continue to work in the financial advice industry if they wished.

AMP says the Halloween cut-off date was not a deadline but more accurately described as a milestone as it pushes ahead with an ambitious program of change.

“AMP wanted to provide sufficient time for practices to consider their options, after which they enter into a transition period appropriate for their choice,” a spokeswoman for AMP said.

“We’ve therefore decided to push back the decision date to November 29. We had already extended the deadline for practices who previously told us they needed more time.”

AMP says it is committed to helping advisers who are ending their association with the firm to choose the right path forward and was supporting them with a range of initiatives as it looked to reshape its business in response to significant disruption and regulatory change.
description: Lawyers acting for AMP planners say their investigations are well advanced and expect to file a class action before the end of the year.
